awd_titl_txt: The Arithmetic of Hypergeometric Varieties and Noncongruence Modular Forms
awd_abstract_narration:
Number theory is one of the scientific backbones of modern digital technology and has important applications in coding theory and cryptography. Beginning with the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem in the 1990's, number theory entered a new era, incorporating rich ideas and tools from other subjects, embracing rapidly-developing mathematical software packages and databases, and building multi-layer platforms and communities for collaborations. This research project investigates modular forms, which are central objects in number theory that occur throughout mathematics and physics. The work aims to broaden and deepen understanding in this fundamental area. The investigator plans to widen the impacts of the research program by continued mentoring of junior mathematicians and organization of national and international workshops and conferences.  

This project investigates the arithmetic of hypergeometric varieties and noncongruence modular forms. A majority of modular forms are noncongruence in the sense that their symmetry groups cannot be described in terms of congruences.  The link between the two topics of study is manifest by the fact that all algebraic curves defined over number fields can be realized as modular curves of finite index subgroups of the modular group. Modular forms are arithmetic invariants of the modular curves. Among all algebraic curves, the generalized Legendre curves are particularly amiable models for both theoretical and computational investigations. Hypergeometric varieties are higher dimensional analogues of the generalized Legendre curves. The objectives of this research project are: (1) to translate a class of classical hypergeometric formulas to the finite field setting; (2) to use these transformation formulas to compute arithmetic invariants of the hypergeometric varieties; (3) to obtain new automorphy results for Galois representations associated with noncongruence modular forms based on explicit Galois representations arising from hypergeometric varieties; and (4) to further investigate other properties of noncongruence modular forms, including a longstanding unbounded denominator conjecture.

por.por_cntn:
As outlined in the proposal, this project contains two parts. In the first part, we continued the study Galois representations arising from noncongruence modular forms. Under the 2-isotypic assumption, Wen-Ching Winnie Li, Tong Liu and the PI showed that these Galois representations are related to Galois representations associated with classical Hecke eigenforms through the perspective of Clifford theory. In a later project, we plan to use such a connection.


On the second closely related topic of hypergeometric functions and motives, we gave a systematic way to study hypergeometric functions over finite fields parallel to the development of classical hypergeometric functions based on the work of Evans, Greene, McCarthy, Ono and others. Using this approach the PI and collaborators obtained many character sum identities which are useful for computing arithmetic invariants. With a Galois interpretation and results from Katz, Beukers-Cohen-Mellit, we gave Galois interpretations of those obtained character sum identities, including a Whipple's $_7F_6(1)$ formula over finite fields. We used  these Galois perspectives to compute hypergeometric L-functions and construct Galois representations with special properties. For example, a Whipple's $_7F_6(1)$ formula was used to construct decomposable hypergeometric representations. These decomposable hypergeometric representations are then used to construct and further obtain the so-called hypergeometric type supercongruences. Using a $p$-adic perturbation method initiated by the PI and Ravi Ramakrishna, combined with a residue sum technique for generating new identities, we obtained several supercongruence results. In one paper joint with Fang-Ting Tu, Noriko Yui and Wadim Zudilin, it is showed that 14 supercongruence conjectures made by Rodriguez-Villegas in 2003 for rigid Calabi-Yau three-folds are true. 


The funded project also led to two research monographs, one on "Hypergeometric Functions over Finite Fields" which was a joint effort with Jenny Fuselier, Ravi Ramakrishna, Holly Swisher, and Fang-Ting Tu; and another one is on "Hypergeometric Functions, Character Sums and Applications" joint with Fang-Ting. Based on the second monograph, the PI gave a lecture series on Hypergeometric Series, which was hosted by University of Connecticut in 2021. 


During the funded period, the PI mentored three Ph.D. students and one postdoc. In 2020, the award was used to support one of the PI's graduate students, Liem Nguyen. Her project was on Weil sum. Because of the support, she finished one paper which has been submitted. The PI also organized a few conferences and workshops.
